Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the present position regarding his Department's plans for the resettlement of travelling people in County Dublin in the light of recent decisions by Dublin County Council; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will now declare that the problem of resettlement of travelling people is a matter to be tackled on a national level; and if he will now set up a task force with the necessary powers to provide halting sites in suitable locations as an intermediate stage in the resettlement of travellers.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the steps he proposes to take to deal with the very serious itinerant problem which exists in the Clondalkin and Tallaght areas of County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Keeffe Mr. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the estimated number of families of travelling people at present; and the plans the Government have to deal with their special housing, educational and health problems.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 209, 210, 211 and 238 together. The primary responsibility for the necessary accommodation of travelling people, whether under the normal housing programme or in special schemes, or on halting sites, rests with the local authorities. My Department give every assistance, including recoupment of full capital costs, of providing special accommodation for travelling people and 90 per cent recoupment of the cost of the employment of social workers. It is also the responsibility of the local authority to initiate any action that may be called for to control unauthorised camping in its administrative area.

Local authorities have been asked to prepare and implement plans to cater for the number of travelling families in need of accommodation in their areas. Consultation between the local authorities has been encouraged in the case of families moving between areas.

As a member of Dublin County Council, Deputy Taylor will be aware that I addressed a special appeal to all the members of the Dublin local authorities on 1 June last stressing the urgent need for a crash programme for settlement of travelling families to deal with the intolerable conditions which have been allowed to develop in certain areas, involving serious suffering for many travelling families and their children, and for the settled community as well.

Some progress has been made but a great deal remains to be done. I have made it clear that I see the answer to this problem in terms of the necessary intensification of effort being applied by the local authorities concerned, in Dublin and elsewhere. I have no proposals for setting up another body to take over those responsibilities.

The Travelling People Review Group which was set up jointly by the Ministers for Health and the Environment in January 1981 to review the current policies and programmes generally in relation to services and support for travelling people is expected to report shortly. Any advice they have to offer in regard to furtherance of the settlement programme will receive close consideration.

The estimated number of travelling families in the country in November 1981 was 2,550, of which 1,350 had been provided for in housing or chalets or approved sites. I have asked local authorities to have a count of travelling people carried out on 16 November 1982 which will give up-dated information on present numbers.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - White Paper on Housing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when he proposes to publish the White Paper on Housing; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: On 30 March 1982 I said in this House that I hoped to have the White Paper published “around the end of this year” (Column 908 of Dáil Official Report). Work has been in progress on a preparatory draft of the White Paper but some interruption occurred because of the need to give priority to the preparation of material for the National Economic Plan 1983 to 1987. I now intend to publish the White Paper during the coming spring.

MainHeading.P: In the meantime, important features of housing policies have been outlined in the plan within the broad framework of the overall economy. In particular, under the plan, the Government are committed for the first time to maintain public capital expenditure on housing in real terms for a period of five years. This commitment will provide a great boost to the housing sector.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - Completion of Estates.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if his Department set out standards or guidelines in relation to how local authorities should ensure that housing developers are capable of completing estates so that they can be taken in charge without expenditure by the local authorities concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: As already announced, I am having a general review of planning law carried out. This will include examination of any change which might improve the existing situation regarding the enforcement of planning control particularly in the case of housing estates. Whatever beneficial changes are identified, will be included in a Planning Bill.

I should, however, point out that the existing enforcement provisions of the Planning Acts are formidable and appear to operate reasonably well. The provisions were considerably strengthened by the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1982, which substantially increased the penalties for planning offences and introduced certain indictable offences, carrying maximum fines of £10,000 or, at the discretion of the courts, imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, or both the fine and imprisonment.

MainHeading.P: Many of the problems in regard to the completion of housing estates appear to stem not from the law as it stands but rather from the operation and implementation of the law. Accordingly, I have issued to planning authorities a substantial memorandum containing advice and guidelines on development control generally. This memorandum contains much that is relevant to housing estates and deals in particular with the type of conditions which should be attached to permissions for estates and the need for care and precision in drafting such permissions if effective enforcement action is to be taken at a later stage. In due course, I hope that it will be possible to prepare additional advisory material relating specifically to the enforcement of planning control.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: I am aware of this publication which, I understand, was presented at a number of conferences and seminars organised by An Foras Forbartha at various centres around the country. Both the conferences and seminars were, I am informed, attended in substantial numbers by relevant technical and administrative officers of local authorities who are, therefore, familiar with its contents and recommendations.

I am, of course, fully conscious of the importance of housing estate layouts which provide a good environment within the constraint of necessary cost limitations. Local authorities are actively encouraged by my Department to achieve good standards of layout in their own housing schemes. In so far as private housing schemes are concerned, they have adequate means available to them through the Development Plans and the operation of planning controls to ensure that similar standards are observed in such schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: I would welcome increased involvement by building societies in the field of voluntary housing bodies and housing co-operatives. My Department have, in fact, discussed this matter both with building society and housing co-operative representatives and I understand from representatives of such co-operatives that the number of building society loans advanced to co-operative members has increased. I also understand that the National Association of Building Co-operatives have identified a number of matters which, in their view, could improve the way in which the building societies deal with housing co-operatives. These matters might, I feel, be discussed between the association and the societies in the first instance but I would, of course, welcome consultation with both parties if, as a result of their discussions, changes in existing legislation were thought necessary.

I am anxious to promote the development of the housing co-operative movement and the National Association of Building Co-operatives are, in fact, grant-aided by my Department. Under the Housing Finance Agency scheme members of housing co-operatives are treated as special category applicants and, as such, are entitled to loans of up to £27,000, instead of the normal maximum of £22,500.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - Report on Illegitimacy.

Speaker.hpid: Miss M. Barry Miss M. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if it is his intention to introduce legislation to abolish the legal status of illegitimacy; and, if so, when.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he intends to amend the law relating to illegitimacy in view of the recent report of the Law Reform Commission; the aspects of their recommendations he is likely to adopt; whether all parts of their report are in accordance with the present policy of the Government; and the likely time scale for amending the law should it be proposed to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 316 and 317 together.

The Law Reform Commission's report on illegitimacy, in which the central recommendation in that the concept of illegitimacy should be removed from the law, was published only very recently — on 15 October last. The report contains in all 68 separate recommendations, many of which are of a fundamental and far-reaching nature. The report is being examined in my Department as well as in some other Departments with an interest in some of the recommendations. This examination is proceeding with all possible speed and the decisions of the Government will be announced as soon as possible. I cannot at this stage anticipate what these decisions will be.

I think it right to mention that the report, as the Commission themselves point out, contains radical proposals and that some of them seem likely to prove to be controversial when people have had time to assess their implications and I would like to encourage all interested persons and organisations to study the report carefully and to make their views on it known.

MainHeading.P: For my own part, I have already indicated more than once that I am sympathetic to the same basic objectives as those underlying the report but, at the same time, it is necessary to stress that the report itself emphasises that complex and far-reaching issues are involved. On the other hand, I am also anxious to ensure that the whole matter is dealt with as quickly as possible and for that reason I would ask that people who have comments to make should send them to me without delay.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - EEC Infrastructure Finance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Donnellan Mr. Donnellan

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: Finance received from the EEC related to infrastructure since Ireland joined the Community comprises—
(a) grant assistance from the European Regional Development Fund and the European Agriculture Guidance and Guarantee Fund totalling £165 million and £13.004 million respectively;
(b) loan assistance from the European Investment Bank and the New Community Instrument totalling £1,016.9 million; and
(c) European Monetary System subsidies, associated with (b), totalling £151.2 million to date.
Further details are set out in the following tables which I propose, with the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, to have circulated with the Official Report.
Category A
(1) Grant assistance from the European Regional Development Fund (established 1975)

ERDF receipts are paid into the Exchequer — not to individual projects — and are applied to increase the State's overall capital expenditure on regional infrastructural development under the following headings:—

MainHeading.P: (2) Grant assistance from the European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund (EAGGF)
Grants relating to infrastructure for Western Drainage (Directive 78/628/EEC) and the Programme for Development in the West of Ireland (Regulation (EEC) 1820/80) can be broken down as follows:

(a) Arterial Drainage: These amounts were spent on the Corrib-Mask-Robe Scheme in Counties Mayo and Galway. A balance of £379,248 is due in respect of 1981 and an advance of £1.8 million was sought for 1982. Neither of these amounts has yet been received. The figure given in the table for 1981 includes £264,678 in respect of 1979 and £630,574 for 1980.

(b) Electricity Supplies: This covers mainly the provision of supply to 2,000 individual farmers throughout the Western Region as well as electricity network improvement under which 22 schemes were either carried out in 1981 or are underway in 1982, as set out below—

row.entry:
Counties Galway, Donegal, Mayo and
Kerry

MainHeading.P: (c) Water Supplies
These comprise—
(i) 334 private group schemes throughout the Western Region
(ii) 7 public schemes as follows— Lettermacaward, Co, Donegal; Mid-Galway; Inishmore; Ballymahon, Co. Longford; Achill Island; Tourmakeady, Co. Mayo; Ballybay, Lough Egish, Co. Monaghan.
(d) Roads: These comprise (i) farm roads (762km) and (ii) County (local) roads (845km) throughout the Western Region.
Category B
Loans from the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the New Community Instrument (NIC) for infrastructure

Note: The above loans, in particular those for telecommunications, water supplies, sewerage and roads, are referable to the Public Capital Programme provisions under the relevant headings which of course include numerous small schemes and relate to the entire country.
Category C
European Monetary System Subsidies
Since 1979 EMS subsidies averaging approximately £45 million a year and totalling £151.2 million to date have been associated with most of EIB and NIC loans set out in category B above.

Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 358, 359 and 360 together.

MainHeading.P: Grant aid of 70 per cent of the estimated cost is provided under the Western Drainage Scheme for a total of 150,000 hectares, the limit set by the EEC which meets 50 per cent of the cost of the scheme. Consideration is being given to the question of how best to provide for these but as only one half of the 150,000 hectares authorised by the EEC has so far been completed, it would be premature at this stage to seek a further extension.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the present position in relation to the closure of the mussel fishery at the mouth of the River Boyne, which has deprived dependent fishermen in the area of a livelihood; when this restriction is likely to end; and if independent studies by Irish authorities, as distinct from authorities overseas, have been provided to him to justify the current restriction.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Woods) Minister for Health (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: It was necessary to prohibit the sale of mussels from the shellfish layings at Mornington, County Meath, because tests had shown that they were so highly contaminated as to constitute a risk to public health. My Department has remained in close touch with the situation. I am sure the Deputy will appreciate that evidence will be needed that the risk to public health has been eliminated before the prohibition can be lifted.
Studies carried out in this country on samples of Mornington mussels were made available to my Department and they justify the action taken. This matter will be kept under review with my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Woods) Minister for Health (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The child referred to in the question has been attending the Eastern Health Board's clinic in Clondalkin for routine dental treatment since November 1975. The child was examined again in October 1982 and has an appointment with the health board's principal dental surgeon for 26 November 1982. Following assessment by the principal dental surgeon the possibility of having any necessary treatment carried out will be considered by the health board.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - Alcohol and Drug Abuse.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is prepared to include in the programme of instruction on the dangers of drug taking proposed for schools in the coming year the basic medical facts on the effects of alcohol abuse in view of the fact that alcohol is more readily available to young people in supermarkets, bars and clubs than other addictive drugs are.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Woods) Minister for Health (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The integrated programme on health education which has been devised by the Health Education Bureau for use in secondary schools comprises nine subject areas. One of these is Substance Abuse. The “substances” in question cover a wide range of drugs including alcohol. The educational material on the alcohol component will include basic medical facts on the effects of alcohol abuse. The whole programme which will be gradually introduced into the schools is designed to be used by teachers in the context of a social and personal development programme for pupils.

MainHeading.P: In addition to the integrated health education programme, the Health Education Bureau has designed a separate Alcohol Education Programme for second level schools. This will provide young people with educational experiences and exercises to enable them to develop healthy mature attitudes towards the use of alcohol. Again, in this programme children will receive factual information, as part of the overall programme, on the immediate, short-term and long-term effects of alcohol and abuse of alcohol on the organs of the human body.

I might mention that the bureau has recently revised its Fact Sheets on Alcohol, a series of 16 information leaflets. These may be used in conjunction with the Alcohol Education Programme or separately. They are available to teachers from the Health Education Bureau.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - Housing Loans for Farmers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keegan Mr. Keegan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will issue guidelines to local authorities setting out the criteria for farmers and self-employed people who do not have P.60 tax forms and who apply for loans to the Housing Finance Agency.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: The question of what guidelines should be issued to local authorities in connection with the Housing Finance Agency scheme is a matter for consideration by the agency in the first instance. I understand that the agency has notified local authorities that self-employed persons, including farmers, should be required to submit certified accounts to establish (a) their eligibility under the scheme; (b) the maximum loan for which they may qualify and (c) the maximum repayment they are required to make in the first year of the loan. Thereafter, they are required to submit annual certified accounts for the purpose of determining the amount of their annual repayment.

Since the inception of the scheme, the agency has discussed the question of possible alternative methods for the assessment of farmers' incomes for the purposes of the scheme with interested bodies, including the Irish Farmers' Association, but no alternative method has been proposed so far by the bodies. I understand that the agency is willing to consider any proposals that may be put to it in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - Sligo Bridge Inquiry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Nealon Mr. Nealon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the number of objections, if any, he has received to the proposed new third bridge in Sligo; the reason for the public inquiry ordered by him into the construction of the bridge; when the inquiry will be held; the likely duration of the public hearing; and the likely time it will take from the ending of the inquiry until a report of the findings is submitted to him.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: In view of the many issues involved, I have decided as provided in section 47 of the Local Government Act, 1946 to cause a local inquiry to be held to consider the Bridge Order application of Sligo Corporation. The inquiry will be held as soon as possible. I cannot anticipate or quantify any of the other matters referred to in the question in advance of the inquiry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Daly)

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Written Answers. - Dublin City Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware of the anxiety being caused to parents and staff of the Christian Brothers School, St. Mary's Place, Dublin 7, in regard to the inadequate financing of various aspects of the school, especially the capitation grant; and if he will outline his proposals for alleviating the distress being caused in this case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Brady, Dublin South-East) Gerard Brady
Speaker.P: Dublin South-East): The amount of capitation grant payable to authorities of national schools is calculated by reference to general regulations related to categories of school. The general rate of grant was £15 per pupil in the 1981-82 school-year, on condition that a local contribution of at least £3.75 per pupil was lodged to the school account. I am not authorised to make additional grants to individual schools.

MainHeading.P: The school board of management is charged with the direct government of the school and is responsible for managing the school finances including the making of arrangements for the collection of such funds locally in supplement of the State grant as will ensure that the school premises will be adequately heated and cleaned and kept in a proper decorative condition.
A special grant of £500 to provide equipment or improvements, particularly in the area of physical education, was allocated to this school in the current year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Brady, Dublin South-East) Gerard Brady
Speaker.P: Dublin South-East): The Commissioners of Public Works have been asked for a report and recommendation regarding essential improvement works at Gardiner Street convent national school, Dublin. A grant will be sanctioned towards the cost of such improvements as are recommended by them.
